column4: can anyone tell me why my Samsung printer isn't showing up as an option to print from anymore?
Has it changed from being your default printer?
it doesn't even seem to be an option.  and the oddest part is, i can't even add a new printer to my system (under system>admin>printers)
it's like something "broke"
Ok - starting from the top, what has changed, been changed, updated, added or modified since it last worked?

hmm, not sure, but i can say that i did a system update yesterday i think and it froze, so i had to do a "dpkg configure -a" or something liek that to fix the broken install.  it was a font package i think.  but other than that, i can't really imagine what else it could be
should i try and reinstall cups maybe?

What would be best to do first and foremost, is delete the printer (if you can), then manually run a package update, then upgrade (make sure nothing further gets broken) then turn off the printer, turn it back on - see if it's "re found"....
just did a reinstall of cups and it worked
Roger that - that's easier.
and also, the printer wasn't showing at all.  strange that it worked now though.  thanks for all the suggestions :)
Just a thought - if this happens again, what about just restarting the cups service?
well, i rebooted to see if that fixed it before and it did not.
Strange that mate.
weird how things just seem to break in ubuntu sometimes. lol

Well, truthfully, it's when the updates hit - or when something gets installed. I've got a few servers sitting around that I just don't touch - and they're happy as Larry - as long as nothing is done to them.
really... so you don't update them at all?
They're servers - they're happy doing what they're doing - the only thing that needs updating is clamav and fprot...nothing more...they're just servers.
what about updates for potential security vulnerabilities?

For all that we're security conscious, when was the last time a nicely locked down linux server was beaten up? "Plan the work, work the plan" - lock it down from the beginning - a server is a server, and when setup exactly as that, well, it's generally quite happy and solid and secure. I'll patch'em after 6 months, otherwise, nothing.
interesting.  thank you for sharing.  never really worked with linux as mainly servers.
They're cheaper and less stress to run for business purposes...do pretty much the same thing...
...they just don't need to be rebooted or "watched for security issues" as much as anything MS
